The lunch bell tinkled. Thea lifted an alternate shot for Merrymount's o≈cial introduction to rosarians, this a day or two older, in a fractionally earlier and more oblique light. Here the outer petals frilled at their edges like gills framing the pleached muss at the center, and the rose showed more of the depth and sweetness of its unforgettable white.

The siskin ducked, half spread its wings, and then changed its mind. What's this? The loathly tabby from next door? No, only dark black Ollie shu∆ing from the kitchen out to the potting shed for lunch with his little grounds crew, mannish Cindy and the new what's-his-name replacement for that ne'er-do-well D.L., who in his short turn had replaced . . . . Thea smiled, loosing a sigh. If senior moments gave any warning one might easier take evasive action. No matter though, when they derailed merely private thought, and not indelible speech that left you twisting in the breeze.

Grizzled Ollie, sheen on his neck bluer than his work shirt, pushed galoshes across the lawn to the edge of the window and past. Because the new rose couldn't possibly have been ''Ruby,'' for Ollie's deceased wife who had once seen to Thea's meals and housekeeping, Thea had proposed ''Ollie,'' and for Wendell Holmes too, but Ollie had begged o√ that commemoration for his years of hybridizing and perfecting the wonder that had sported on his watch.

Thea shook the last shot from its glassine. Just maybe. Here the face lolling more toward the lens presented the best resolutionwith a magnifying glass one might almost count the score of petals crowded into each quarter and trace veins in the leaves and swollen bud. Thea tilted the photo. Surely Marvin would have favored this one, and would surely have approved the name, from the Hawthorne (lovely name itself) tale they had read in the American belles lettres class down in Chapel Hill where they had met. Truth to tell, though, Marvin, gone these decades, sometimes seemed scarcely a dream.

In her and his deliberations about a name for their earlier specimen candidate, a rose that had never given up reverting, they had ruled out either of their own names, along with available Y names of the eminent and historical, and imaginary personages. Peace, the rose of that century in its first flush of popularity, had swayed them toward similar abstractions, but none had prevailed before the entire question became moot. Marvin would have enjoyed the idea of Hawthorne's gay community returning as a lovely rose, in triumph over its Puritan enemies, and he would have savored the initial and terminal resonances with his name.

The die was cast in any case. Merrymount it was, to the rosarian inspection committee that had granted its imprimatur two Septembers ago, Merrymount in the ensuing discourse, and now, soon, in the exclusive catalogue that in fall would o√er a limited quantity at a designedly exorbitant premium to a hungry and discriminating public persuaded by . . . perhaps the first photo after all, its color perhaps less false -had something in the stratosphere burned away? -if not precisely truer, and in any case Merrymount's wavering and addictive creaminess would have eluded even Vermeer.

A cool breeze wandered through the open windows of the potting shed, and through the doorway, where Ollie had left even the screen door ajar (no mosquitoes yet) for lunch. Ollie eased himself down onto the bench where he could rest his back against a stanchion. He opened his lunch box on his lap and snapped the thermos from the lid. He clicked o√ its plastic cup, set it on the bench, unscrewed the stopper, poured half a cup of cold sweet tea, sni√ed it as when the mood struck him to savor its light resemblance to attar of roses, especially pleasing in this indirect green noon light filtering through the ivied panes. Ollie lifted out his egg salad sandwich, laid it on his knees, and unfolded its waxed paper.

At the doorway Rafe skimmed o√ his headphones and switched o√ the set at his belt. ''All mowed in front.'' He shook the creases of his chinos to release grass snippets. Past the threshold he scooped his ziplock lunch of cheese biscuits and root beer o√ a shelf and pulled a stool up to the worktable. ''Rain holds o√, I should be able to edge this afternoon. But the lawn could use rain.'' ''Rain?'' Cindy do√ed goatskin gloves in the doorway and dropped them with her secateur and neckerchief on the orange metal garden chair before stepping inside. ' Rafe showed palms, fanning fingers. ''I didn't even take sociology. So, are you and Ruthie still an item? How'd you derail her, by the way, strategic knee to the family jewels?'' ''More civilized. We can be gentlemanly as the next man. Ruthie was cool. We talked a little more and then I drove back to Carrboro. My softball team plays in Charlotte Saturday and she'd talked about driving over, but now I think maybe better not, after this little contretemps. Give ourselves a breather.'' As the trio mused, eyes lowered and unfocused, the green light darkened. Presently fingers of rain tapped across the metal roof. At length Cindy said, ''So, Ollie, is Merrymount set to ship?'' She reminded Rafe of the debut. ''We'll mail bare-root.'' ''You mean we, or you, will have to wash down the youngsters you've shepherded through their first winter, just when their little rootlets are stretching and branching, just as they're learning the Y meaning of home? May as well aquaculture from day one, seems to me. Then we'd only need pat dry their toesies.'' ''He's flabbergasting me, Cindy. If we sign this young Turk on, we'll both find ourselves sidelined before the year's out.'' Rafe grinned. ''That's no answer, man.''

The siskin groomed under a wing, flu√ed, shook, laid feathers back against its body, and sighted across the lawn through fine rain to movement upstairs in the circle of ivy, Thea. ''These days we're ready for most anything to fall out of the sky, shuttle parts, body parts, coronaviruses, tornadoes, but you I wouldn't quite have imagined, little one.'' The squirrel guard, a transparent hemisphere above the feeder, provided a good umbrella. For the hundredth time Thea thought about the Merrymount price. She didn't want it out of reach of ordinary people, retired people who needed beauty, more and more, it seemed. At the same time the price should be high enough to cultivate the rose, for it to establish itself in gardens across the piedmont, the South, even across the land to the Northwest, where it would surely thrive, and California, and be known and loved long after Thea breathed her last, one among the multitude of these most loved flowers, and not the least lovely, or the least loved.

Ollie mused. ''Sometimes Ruby'd surprise me. Home from here, in the doorway I might smell low-country mud bugs cooking and think, 'Girl, you're beautiful.' Ruby was substantial, always outweighed me. And solemn. Getting a smile took work, and sometimes stealth, but her dimples were worth it.'' ''Beautiful?'' Rafe ventured. ''To me at least, you mean? Well, not exactly that way.'' Those dimples, her yellow eyes, how light Ruby seemed, negotiating past our Hoover in the hall closet. Or she'd dozed in front of the television before we had color, and blue dust seemed drifted over her arms and face and like a bloom on her silver braids. Ollie sighed. ''I don't know what she would think to hear me talking about her this way to you children, but no, what I remember feeling those times was more a tenderness, the chill a baby can give you, and also privilege, that could nearly . . . . '' Ollie considered. ''I don't mean often. Truth to tell, maybe not ever. But from time to time the possibility would slip up on me, that the privilege of just being next to her, just her breathing might turn my knees to jelly.'' Rafe mused, ''When you're a arthur or arthuress, you write about beautiful flowers and so forth, right? Velvet and candelabras, like in easy listening. Babes in stilettos.'' Cindy said, ''Unless you make whatever you write about flowery itself.'' She turned to Ollie. ''Isn't that the same as soul?'' ''Get outta here.'' ''Whatever. Anyhow Rafey, I don't think you need bother with the laptop song and dance. Invest in an actual violin. On eBay, a high school orchestra gone belly up. Maybe a collapsible music stand. Display them negligently in your pad, you score with nine bimbos out of ten.'' Rafe smiled. ''What if one asks for a performance?'' ''Beg o√, son,'' advised Ollie. ''O√er a rain check. You're too serious a musician to play unless your heart's in it.'' Cindy said, ''Alternatively, how about lessons? Find a local bluegrass fiddler down on her luck. For a song you'll be cranking out moonlight and roses to beat the band.'' ''Or,'' said Ollie, ''while you're on eBay check for performance enhancers. Pop one with your last sports-bar beer. By the time she crosses your threshold you're ready to rock.'' ''Wonders of science,'' said Rafe. ''You a musician, man?'' ''Ruby and I got down Saturday nights with other youngsters in the back room of the billiards hall, improvising, learning as we went.'' Cindy said, ''I didn't know that, Ollie. What instrument?'' ''Washtub bass. Ruby washboard, like we were meant for each other.'' Rafe said, ''You must have made beautiful music together.'' Ollie chuckled. ''I won't deny it. No, but here's a pearl of wisdom, for the both of you. Get enough years under your belts and any music is beautiful by definition.'' ''We'll see,'' Cindy said sociably, refraining from voicing reservations about rap and medieval, and other aesthetic considerations she didn't expect would change. Men for instance, God love 'em, for this girl they'll never be anything but comic. Feet for starters. But I'm laid back. Take this Merrymount. Not to put too fine a point on it, the scheme is fundamentally cranky. Next thing you Y know we'll be introducing jellyfish genes for luminescence. Now would be the time to nip this particular innovation in the bud, before stock ships. With gasoline or even the right herbicide it could look accidental. Should it break Mrs. Hunt's old heart, or Ollie's, well, you make an omelet, you break eggs. Anyway, hearts mend. She continued, ''I can barely carry a tune myself. Still, I whistle in the dark when it helps. How about you, Rafe?'' She turned to Ollie. ' ''I've passed probation then?'' Cindy gave a questioning smile to Ollie, who considered. ''Whatever,'' said Rafe. ''Anyway I'm not sure I'd normalize even if I could. The quirk has uses. I recognize voices the way a dog does smell. Even on the phone or in a recording, couple of words and I know who it is, if I've ever heard it before, and if not, I know that. When I can't place a face I just get it to say something.'' ''Human, you mean?'' ''Humanoid even, robots. Nonhuman animals less, but more than you might guess. Plus also I process extra-low volume. Blindfolded, I still hear space.'' Cindy said, ''You never know when that talent will come in handy. Pin the tail on the donkey.'' Ollie said, ''Handy if he lost his sight for sure.'' He touched the wooden bench.

Rafe said, ''I save on electricity when I have to pee at night. I don't bump things even in a strange place.'' Cindy said, ''You're often in strange places in the dark?'' ''Not often enough. You?'' She shrugged. ''Some places are stranger than others. But I The siskin buzzed cheerily, flu√ed, and shook. Thea raised binoculars that had served her half a century and more. The siskin cocked a bright eye her way, as if to say, ''Bzzzt! Bzzzt, Thea Pettigrew Hunt, bzzzzzt!'' Momentarily it would take wing, and swoop through the clearing rain over the rose beds and away. In the interim, shouldn't one hazard a wish? As best she still could, Thea opened her mind to let one appear. What appeared, however, was a shred of memory, of the tipsy gaiety of the celebrants in ''The Maypole of Merry Mount,'' the twice-told tale she and Marvin had pored over in the Riverside series ''Edited for Study'' on their first date, the silken banner staining the pale shaft with the seven rainbow hues. As the pair sought the allegorical lesson, paging forward and back on the oak table in the library reading room, a Friday evening in April, possibly her hand had brushed his, or vice versa. There had been a dancing bear (what an idea!) that the Puritans had shot in the head. With all the earnestness of youth Thea had debated the meaning, why the poor beast had taken the bullet in its head rather than in its heart, and what might have been the color of the nameless roses wreathed in the pine boughs above.

The siskin opened its beak as if to sing again, but instead the little stranger merely gave a kind of avian yawn and leapt o√ the feeder into a loop-the-loop out of sight. Thea nodded and set down her binoculars beside the dear glossies. ''Well and good.''

BIBREF2.title: But shouldn't you engineer sound or something, rather than gardening flowers? It strikes me we three should keep this to ourselves, by the way. No need for Mrs. Hunt to lose sleep Y over it. But it's boggling, to think someone's never truly seen the rainbow.'' ''Agreed, but, you want more boggle?'' Cindy said, ''From you, sure.'' ''I can hear the rainbow. I hear it. Nothing else sounds like it.'' ''I think he's pulling our legs, Cindy.'' ''I didn't expect you to believe me. I only wish there was some way to reproduce for you what I hear, but mostly I can't even describe it to myself. Rainbows, for instance. I've never heard one begin or end. When I notice it, it's already there, sort of a deeper clarity
BIBREF2.venue: Okay, full disclosure, probation be damned. It's that my hearing may have hypertrophied in connection with a mild visual disability. No biggie, and it shouldn't disqualify me from lawn and garden work

Ollie rooted in his curls. ''Seems to me it ends today.'' ''I forget,'' said Rafe. ''You guys must have informed me, but that was then. So what is it with this probation? I keep my nose clean for a month and then what, I finally meet Ms. Hunt? So then, everybody have a good weekend? Any progress with the new Cindy waved concerns away with the shaggy leg. ''He's barely out of his nappies, Ollie. We can cut him some slack. No, but it felt weird, 2 a.m., not much stirring. You still crashing over there, Rafe?'' He nodded. ''But with a di√erent pal. I may have something here lined up though. Out from Hillsborough village but still in the town. There might be some contact glamour I could use.'' '' 'Use'?'' ''Hook-ups, whatever. That extra little nudge. Plus it's easier if you have your own place you can invite them to, in case they have a roommate. If not, you can say we'll check out Hillsborough next actually -to be factoring in real estate.'' Cindy shook her head. ''Whole new world, Ollie. Even I didn't turn businesslike as early as kids do now. The silicon collapse started it, and then terrorism. They snag MBAs before they graduate high school. But a gold digger might wise up if Rafe did ever bring her home.'' Rafe nodded. ''Especially if it's only a trailer. No, but I had another angle in mind. I could cruise by here, explain it's mine but I'm like camping out. I'm a arthur knocking out a booklet of experiences. Whatever.'' ''Might fly,'' said Cindy. ''Except, suppose lights are still on and Mrs. Hunt chooses that moment to drift past a window?'' ''That's Mom, or even a housekeeper. Needn't be elaborate.'' Ollie asked, ''A booklet?'' ''You think a whole book might work better? Check. Six of one.'' ''You have a laptop?'' ''I'll say it's in the shop.'' ''How about this,'' o√ered Ollie. ''You're an entomologist, camping out to observe ants. Thrips.'' Cindy shook her head. ''How can he work his wiles when she's thinking there might be specimens under any pillow?'' Rafe said, ''Anyway I want it to sound true. Lots of arthurs live around here, right?'' ''That's the word on the street,'' said Cindy. ''Not just here either -the whole Triangle. Lesbians too.'' ''Why do you suppose that is?'' Ollie chuckled. ''Don't look at me.'' Cindy said, ''Momentum, I think. A couple puts down roots almost by chance, and that starts the colonization.''''I do seem to have run across more of your sisters than seems normal. Could there be a connection?'' ''He's losing me,'' said Ollie. ''Arthurs and dykes,'' Rafe explained. ''Not that you couldn't be both, but I was wondering if there might be some kind of symbiosis or mutual attraction. Birds of a feather, both loners. Anyway I've known a couple or three ladies that were arthur groupies, if you will. That gave me the idea of capitalizing on Hillsborough's reputation.'' ''Tell you the truth, man,'' Cindy said, ''I honestly don't see why you should need help, with that killer smile.'' ''Guys,'' Rafe protested, ''let's not forget Ruthie. She's turning into a cli√hanger. She's put on her best seduction mix, you've done a couple of joints, lights o√ except the lava lamp. Who jumps who?'' ''Nobody. We messed around some, until she wanted to tie me up. Said I'd like it better than she would. Nothing rough, just a way to demonstrate trust.Except insofar as all talk may partly be reparative. But why do you ask? Were you about to stake your claim?'' Rafe said, ''What claim could she have? Her grievance isn't inherited, according to the little I know about it.'' ''What's the di√,'' asked Cindy. ''But okay, Ollie, let's let that particular can of worms lie, unless this whippersnapper wants to untangle it for us.''

TABREF1.text: 'Maybe he doesn't need lessons. Maybe he's already some kind of Paganini.'' ''What it is,'' Rafe confessed, ''is, I hear too much. I can carry a tune, but it's no breeze. I'm like missing a filter.'' Ollie said, ''To block . . . ?'' ''Overtones, sound shapes. Patterns fail to register. My brain lets too much through.'' ''Like with amplifiers?'' ''Not exactly. It's more informational. I get extra spam.'' ''Bummer,'' said Cindy. ''Don't forget health insurance,'' Ollie observed. ''Here in the Triangle you could find good help. Might just be wiring.''
